file_content.text: Your shuttle is ready to launch.
Welcome to Quesh!
You folks here to fight?
Haven't seen that many Jedi in this sector. You here for the war effort?
You're with Havoc Squad, right? It's good to see more special forces arriving. Here to kick some Imperial butt?
Not much trade opportunity at the moment. You here for the war?
What brings you to Quesh? Are you looking to fight Imperials?
I certainly hope you're not here for the sights. Although the poisonous gas makes for pretty sunsets, I suppose.
Speaking of which, you'll need this to survive in Quesh's atmosphere. When it starts to wear off, see a medic for another shot.
Why would the Republic fight for a poisonous planet?
What's our interest in Quesh?
This location must be important to the Republic. What's the story?
What's our mission here?
This planet has poisonous air? Has the Republic lost its mind?
Wait, the air is toxic?
Tell me what's down there.
I've barely seen the place. I came here with a team to study the planet, but we've been forced by the Empire to evacuate.
How will I know when it's wearing off?
How long does this last?
Symptoms include dizziness, headache, nausea, mania, burning in extremities, hallucinations, dry mouth and death.
Although deadly in its natural state, Quesh venom, the chemical in the air, can be used to make powerful adrenals.
The Empire found out about our mining operations here and filled the planet with troops and battle droids.
I imagine that waging war on a planet with toxic air doesn't work out well.
That makes this more tricky.
The air's not as bad as the terrain. Quesh is all swamp. Hard on machinery, harder on soldiers.
We're not going to defeat the Empire with chit-chat.
Enough talk already.
Poisonous and under attack?
Well, you're cleared to travel to the planet's surface. Just say the word.
I'm ready to have a look at this poison planet.
Let's go.
Speak to General Korvan when you land. He'll brief you on the current situation. Good luck.
I have some preparations to make before I go.
I'm not ready yet.
Of course. The shuttle is standing by.
Sorry, we're doing a pre-flight check of the shuttles. You'll have to come back later.
